member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.TimeCodePreset.#ctor(Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode)
member.summary: Sets the Time Code Generator value to the time code indicated by DATA-1 thru DATA-4. The Data format is as per the 24.31 Cue Up With Data Cmd1, with two additional bits to indicate Color Frame and Drop Frame mode as follows:

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.Timer1Reset.#ctor
member.summary: Sets the Timer-1 value to the time code indicated by DATA-1 thru DATA-4. For the time format see the 24.31 Cue Up With Data command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.OutPlusShift.#ctor
member.summary: Increments the Video out point by one frame.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.OutMinusShift.#ctor
member.summary: Decrements the Video out point by one frame.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.OutFlagReset.#ctor
member.summary: Sets the Video out point to the value displayed on the _slave. This is the value of the selected tape timer.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.OutEntry.#ctor
member.summary: Sets the Video out point to the value displayed on the _slave. This is the value of the selected tape timer.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.InPlusShift.#ctor
member.summary: Increments the Video in point by one frame.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.InMinusShift.#ctor
member.summary: Decrements the Video in point by one frame.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.InFlagReset.#ctor
member.summary: Sets the Video in point to the value displayed on the _slave. This is the value of the selected tape timer.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.PresetSelectControl.InEntry.#ctor
member.summary: Sets the Video in point to the value displayed on the _slave. This is the value of the selected tape timer.

member.summary: Set the Audio In Point to the value indicated by DATA-1 thru DATA-4. The time format is as per the 24.31 Cue Up With Data command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.AutoEdit.#ctor
member.summary: When one of these commands is received the _slave goes into the indicated mode

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.AntiClogTimerDisable.#ctor
member.summary: Disables the anti-clog timer. This timer is responsible for unthreading the tape upon timeout to save wear on the heads. If a system disables this timer, it should take responsibility for head wear avoidance itself.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.AudioInEntry.#ctor
member.summary: Sets the audio in point to the value displayed on the _slave. This is the value of the selected tape timer.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.AudioOutEntry.#ctor
member.summary: Sets the audio out point to the value displayed on the _slave. This is the value of the selected tape timer.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.AudioOutDataPreset.#ctor(Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode)
member.summary: Set the Audio Out Point to the value indicated by DATA-1 thru DATA-4. The time format is as per the 24.31 Cue Up With Data command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.ShuttleRev.#ctor(System.Byte)
member.summary: When receiving one of the above commands, the _slave will start running in accordance with the speed Data defined by DATA-1 and DATA-2. For the maximum and minimum speed see the 2X.12 Shuttle Fwd Cmd1.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.ShuttleRev.#ctor(System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: When receiving one of the above commands, the _slave will start running in accordance with the speed Data defined by DATA-1 and DATA-2. For the maximum and minimum speed see the 2X.12 Shuttle Fwd Cmd1.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.ShuttleFwd.#ctor(System.Byte)
member.summary: When these commands are received the _slave device will move forward with the speed indicated by DATA-1 and DATA-2.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.ShuttleFwd.#ctor(System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: When these commands are received the _slave device will move forward with the speed indicated by DATA-1 and DATA-2.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.InDataPreset.#ctor(Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode)
member.summary: Set the Video In Point to the value indicated by DATA-1 thru DATA-4. The time format is as per the 24.31 Cue Up With Data command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.OutDataPreset.#ctor(Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode)
member.summary: Set the Video Out Point to the value indicated by DATA-1 thru DATA-4. The time format is as per the 24.31 Cue Up With Data command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.CueUpWithData.#ctor(Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode)
member.summary: Cues the _slave to the indicated time.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.VarRev.#ctor
member.summary: When receiving one of the above commands, the _slave will start running in accordance with the speed Data defined by DATA-1 and DATA-2. For the maximum and minimum speed see the 2X.12 Shuttle Fwd command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.VarFwd.#ctor
member.summary: When these commands are received the _slave device will move forward with the speed indicated by DATA-1 and DATA-2.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.SyncPlay.#ctor
member.summary: Prerolls the _slave for the preset Preroll time, then enters Play mode.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.Stop.#ctor
member.summary: This command places the Video disk recorder in the Stop mode, and any “motion” command such as Play, fast forward, Record, etc., will Stop. This command will immediately abort any current auto Play or Record process, but will not reset the auto mode presets and Preview presets. When a Stop command is issued, the Stop status (status byte 1, bit 5) will be set high, and the Rewind status (status byte 1, bit 3), fast forward status (status byte 1, bit 2), Record status (status byte 1, bit 1), Play status (status byte 1, bit 0), Shuttle status (status byte 2, bit 5), Jog status (status byte 2, bit 4), and variable Play status (status byte 2, bit 3) will all be set low.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.StandbyOn.#ctor
member.summary: Turns on Standby mode. For VTR, this causes the machine to stay threaded when in Stop. Affects EE/Tape selection.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.StandbyOff.#ctor
member.summary: Turns off Standby mode. For VTR, this causes the machine to unthread in Stop. Affects EE/Tape selection. Available only in Stop mode.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.Rewind.#ctor
member.summary: When it receives this command, the _slave runs in reverse at maximum speed: on the DVR2000, this is 50xplay speed.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.Review.#ctor
member.summary: When one of these commands is received the _slave goes into the indicated mode

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.Record.#ctor
member.summary: This command places the Video disk recorder in the Record mode, and recording will begin. Recording begins from the current time code position on the currently loaded Id, and the time code position will increase and new Video material will be recorded until recording is stopped. If auto mode is enabled, the Record command will initiate the auto Record processing described under the auto mode on command (40.41). There should be a fixed latency in number of frames from the time this command is issued, after a Record cue is issued, until the Video disk recorder actually starts recording, so that the controlling device can frame accurately synchronize the source material. When a Record command is issued, the Stop status (status byte 1, bit 5) will be set low, and the Record status (status byte 1, bit 1), Play status (status byte 1, bit 0) and servo lock status (status byte 2, bit 7) will be set high.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.ProgSpeedPlayPlus.#ctor
member.summary: This command Play back the _slave device in steps of 0.1% within the range of +/- 25.5% of Play speed. DATA-1 contains an 8-bit speed value. The deviation from nominal Play speed is: Deviation(%)=0.1 x speed value

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.ProgSpeedPlayMin.#ctor
member.summary: This command Play back the _slave device in steps of 0.1% within the range of +/- 25.5% of Play speed. DATA-1 contains an 8-bit speed value. The deviation from nominal Play speed is: Deviation(%)=0.1 x speed value

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.Preview.#ctor
member.summary: When one of these commands is received the _slave goes into the indicated mode

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.Preroll.#ctor
member.summary: When this command is received the _slave will search to the Preroll position defined as the value obtained by subtracting the Preroll time set by the 44.31 Preroll Time Preset command from the IN POINT Data stored in the IN ENTRY memory by the 40.10 In Entry command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.Play.#ctor
member.summary: This command places the Video disk recorder in the Play mode, and playback will begin. Playback begins from the current time code position on the currently loaded Id, and the time code position will increase and new Video material will be output until playback is stopped. If auto mode is enabled, the Play command will initiate the auto Play processing described under the auto mode on command (40.41). There should be a fixed latency in number of frames from the time this command is issued, after a Play cue or in preset is issued, until the Video disk recorder actually starts playback, so that the controlling device can frame accurately synchronize the source material. When a Play command is issued, the Stop status (status byte 1, bit 5) will be set low, and the Play status (status byte 1, bit 0) and servo lock status (status byte 2, bit 7) will be set high.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.OutpointPreview.#ctor
member.summary: Sends transport to preset out point if Insert mode is preset.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.JogRev.#ctor
member.summary: When receiving one of the above commands, the _slave will start running in accordance with the speed Data defined by DATA-1 and DATA-2. For the maximum and minimum speed see the 2X.12 Shuttle Fwd command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.EditOn.#ctor
member.summary: This command is used to actually initiate recording. When the device is playing, and the Edit presets set by the 4X 30 Edit Preset command are in place, the preset channels will enter Record a fixed delay after this command is received. The _slave will enter Edit Rec mode at this point. It takes the _slave 5 frames to enter Edit Rec after receiving this command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.FreezeOff.#ctor
member.summary: This command un-freezes the output of the device.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.FreezeOn.#ctor
member.summary: This command freezes the output of the device. There is usually a 2-5 frame delay associcated with the actual freeze.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.EditOff.#ctor
member.summary: This command will Stop recording without affecting the state of motion of the device. Any channels in Record will come out in response to this command, after 5 frames of delay. This command also clears the Manual Edit Record mode and the Select EE mode.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.FastFwd.#ctor
member.summary: When this command is received, the _slave device will run in fast forward mode. The speed depends on the VTR; for the DVR2000 series it is 50 x Play speed.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.FullEEOff.#ctor
member.summary: Clears all channels from EE mode regardless of EDIT PRESET channels assigned by the 41.30 EDIT PRESET command. It takes the _slave 5 frames to perform this operation after it receieves the command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.FullEEOn.#ctor
member.summary: Sets all channels to EE mode regardless of EDIT PRESET channels assigned by the 41.30 EDIT PRESET command. It takes the _slave 5 frames to perform this operation after it receieves the command.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.Eject.#ctor
member.summary: When this command is received, the _slave will Eject the tape.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.TransportControl.SelectEEOn.#ctor
member.summary: This command sets only the preset channels assigned by the 41.30 Edit Preset command to EE mode. The EE mode is cleared by the 20.64 Edit Off command. It takes the _slave 5 frames to perform this operation after receiving the command.

member.name: F:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.Return.NakCommandBlock.Nak.TimeOut
member.summary: This bit is high when a communications time out error has occurred, otherwise it is low.

members.member: This bit is high when a communications framing error has occurred, otherwise it is low.
.This bit is high when a communications overrun error has occurred, otherwise it is low.
This bit is high when a communications parity error has occurred, otherwise it is low.
This bit is high when a communications checksum error has occurred, otherwise it is low.
This bit is high when an undefined command error has occurred, otherwise it is low.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.CommandBlock.TryParse(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Byte},Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.CommandBlock@)
member.summary: Converts the byte array representation of a commandblock. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded.
member.param: A byte array containing a CommandBlock to convert.

When this method returns, contains the CommandBlock value equivalent of the buffer contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not of the correct format. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false

member.summary: Calculate the checksum based on the current fields

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.UserBitPreset.#ctor
member.summary: This command presets the value given by DATA-1 through DATA-4 to the User Bits of the Time Code Generator.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.SystemControl.LocalEnable.#ctor
member.summary: Enable operation of _slave device from Local panel according to the Local enable map set by the "4XB8" Local Key Map command

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.SystemControl.LocalDisable.#ctor
member.summary: Disable operation of the _slave device from its control panel

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.SystemControl.DeviceTypeRequest.#ctor
member.summary: This response is returned for a Device Type Request (00.11) command. Two bytes of Data will be returned with this response. The first byte is generally used as a category of device, and the second byte is generally used as a model number for the device. Although not officially specified, some Video cassette recorder implementations use the least significant bit of the category byte of the device type to indicate if the device is configured for NTSC (bit low) or PAL (bit high). Video disk recorder manufacturers must assign a unique number for their category and models, and should be careful to avoid conflicting with existing device types.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. Constructor

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. Copy Constructor

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.AutoMode
member.summary: This bit is set high when auto mode is enable, low when auto mode is disabled.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Busy
member.summary: This bit is high if the Video disk recorder can not accept motion commands or other commands requiring time consuming processing, low if those commands can be accepted. Note that status commands and other sensing commands must always be processed, even if this bit is set high.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.CueUp
member.summary: This bit is set high at the completion of a Play/Record cue command or Preset In command. It is set low on initialization, and any time the current time code position changes due to a motion command, etc.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Eject
member.summary: This bit is high while ejecting.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.FastFwd
member.summary: This bit is high when in fast forward mode, low for other modes.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.HardError
member.summary: This bit is high if a hardware error or other unrecoverable error is encountered, low if no such error has occurred.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.In
member.summary: This bit is set high if the auto mode in preset references a valid Id and contains a valid time code position. Otherwise, it is set low.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Jog
member.summary: This bit is high when in Jog mode, low for other modes.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Local
member.summary: This bit is high if the Video disk recorder is under Local control, low if remote control is enabled. Status sense is always available to the controlling device, even under Local control.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Out
member.summary: This bit is set high if the auto mode out preset contains a valid time code position. Otherwise, it is set low.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Play
member.summary: This bit is high when in Play or Record mode, low for other modes.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Preroll
member.summary: This bit is set high while cueing (following the issuing of a Record/Play cue command or Preset In command), and is set low high at completion.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.PreviewInPreset
member.summary: This bit is set high if the auto mode Preview in preset references a valid Id and contains a valid time code position. Otherwise, it is set low. The auto mode Preview presets will become invalid, and this bit will be set low, when the auto mode Preview presets are shifted to the auto mode presets as part of the auto Play processing. This will be the means by which a controlling device can determine when it can set new values for the auto mode Preview presets.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.PreviewOutPreset
member.summary: This bit is set high if the auto mode Preview out preset contains a valid time code position. Otherwise, it is set low. The auto mode Preview presets will become invalid, and this bit will be set low, when the auto mode Preview presets are shifted to the auto mode presets as part of the auto Play processing. This will be the means by which a controlling device can determine when it can set new values for the auto mode Preview presets.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Record
member.summary: This bit is high when in Record mode, low for other modes.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Rewind
member.summary: This bit is high when in Rewind mode, low for other modes.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.ServoLock
member.summary: This bit is high when a Play or Record mode is active, low for other modes such as when the output is not genlocked to the reference. While servo lock probably has no meaning for a Video disk recorder, this status bit is provided in order to maintain compatibility with existing Video cassette recorder implementations.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Shuttle
member.summary: This bit is high when in Shuttle mode, low for other modes.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Still
member.summary: This bit is high when time code is not changing (stopped, Still, zero speed Shuttle, Jog, or variable Play, etc.).

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Stop
member.summary: This bit is high when in Stop mode, low for other modes.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.TapeDir
member.summary: This bit is low when time code is increasing (“moving” forward), high when time code is decreasing (“moving” in reverse).

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.TapeEnd
member.summary: This bit is set high when the current time code position has reached its maximum value and can not increase (“move” forward). Once set, this bit will be cleared (set low) by any movement command (Play, Rewind, etc.), and will continue to be set low as long as the current time code position can increase (“move” forward). This bit is also used during recording to indicate to the controlling device that there is no more available storage in the Video disk recorder.

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.TapeTop
member.summary: This bit is set high when the current time code position has reached its minimum value and can not decrease (“move” in reverse). Once set, this bit will be cleared (set low) by any movement command (Play, Rewind, etc.), and will continue to be set low as long as the current time code position can decrease (“move” in reverse).

member.name: P:Acme.Sony9Pin.CommandBlocks.StatusData.StatusData.Var
member.summary: This bit is high when in variable Play mode, low for other modes.

member.name: T:Acme.Sony9Pin.Sony9PinMaster
member.summary: The sony 9 pin master. The protocol is initiated by the master. The slave should return a response within 9 msec. The response may be: NAK + Error Data: Undefined Cmd1 or communication error COMMAND + Data: if Cmd1 requested data ACK: if Cmd1 did not request data The master should not send another Cmd1 until receiving a response from the slave device. The master must also insure that no more than 10 msec lapses between bytes in a Cmd1 block. The master must immediatly stop sending data when it receives a NAK + Error Data message. If the Error Data contains "Undefined Cmd1" the master may immediatley send another Cmd1, otherwise it must wait at least 10 msec before sending another Cmd1. When the master does not receive a response from the slave within the 10 msec timeout, it may assume that communications have ceased and take appropriate measures.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.Sony9PinMaster.#ctor

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary:
Constructor from sony9pin protocol bytes
data-1 data-2 data-3 data-4 | Frame | | Seconds | | minutes | | hours | | 10 1 | | 10 1 | | 10 1 | | 10 1 |
auth - this is how time is represented in all commands and responses using a time code. The numbers indicate that the 10s value is stored in the high nibble and the 1s value in the low nibble. This is not to be confused with the 80-bit SMPTE timecode which is present in the analog timecode track on tape, or with the VITC timecode.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode.FromBytes(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Convert a byte array (in reversed order, as given by the BVW75 protocol) to a TimeCode

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode.FromTimeSpan(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Convert a timespan to a timecode

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parse a timecode string into a timecode. Can throw an exception upon failure.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode.TryParse(System.String,Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode@)
member.summary: Try to Parse a timecode string into a timecode. returns true on success (giving 'result' the corresponding, valid timecode) returns false on failure (giving 'result' a null value, because it is undefined)

member.summary: fetch the data, in an atomic thread-safe way

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode.SetData(System.Byte[])
member.summary:
Set the data from a byte array, in an atomic thread-safe way
data-1 data-2 data-3 data-4 | Frame | | Seconds | | minutes | | hours | | 10 1 | | 10 1 | | 10 1 | | 10 1 |
auth - this is how time is represented in all commands and responses using a time code. The numbers indicate that the 10s value is stored in the high nibble and the 1s value in the low nibble. This is not to be confused with the 80-bit SMPTE timecode which is present in the analog timecode track on tape, or with the VITC timecode.

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode.SetData(Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode)
member.summary: Set the data from the other timecode

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode.SetData(System.String)
member.summary: Set the data from a string format: [-]hh:mm:ss:ff or [-]hh:mm:ss:mil (note: ',' instead of ':' is also allowed, as well as mixing ',' and ':')

member.name: M:Acme.Sony9Pin.TimeCode.SetData(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the data from separate values: hours, minutes, seconds, frames

member.summary: Set the data from separate values: hours, minutes, seconds, frames, ticks
